reasoning: The critique targets one sub-argument in the essay: that (difference-making) bounded views which aggregate goods and bads separately become extremely “fussy” because even a tiny fraction of “bads” can prevent a mostly-great future. This is relevant but not central to the overall “no easy eutopia” conclusion, which is also supported by independent arguments (historical moral catastrophes, multiplicative fragility, unbounded/linear views, fat-tailed value-efficiency, etc.). The critique has limited strength because it largely reads the paper’s separate-aggregation asymmetry example as relying on an extreme, near-lexical priority for avoiding bads; but the paper also argues fussiness even for symmetric separate-aggregation, and the ‘one star of bad’ claim is conditional on specific normalization/bounding assumptions rather than straightforward negative utilitarian dominance. Still, it is partly correct that the paper’s strongest-sounding illustration depends on contestable modeling choices (separate aggregation + strong asymmetry + the particular scaling). The critique is clear, focused on a single issue, and contains little dead weight, but it overstates how much the paper’s conclusion depends on the extreme asymmetric case.
title: Extreme negative-dominance assumptions make bounded views seem implausibly fussy
